Great @rabbah! Hopefully this will speed up the discussion and solve the problem in #3603.

@rabbah @fmaschler My 2 cents.. I have found that both the approaches have their limitations.
Using a non-root user within the container works for controller and action containers but does not work for invoker since invoker needs privileged access to create action containers.

A User namespace has its own limitations documented here. https://docs.docker.com/engine/security/userns-remap/#user-namespace-known-limitations
One of the limitations listed is pid=host which is the default ansible config in OW Invoker.

The best practice as per docker seems to " configure your container’s applications to run as unprivileged users"
LGTM 👍

@mcdan is this really based on splunk user and not on the timestamp of log events sent to splunk? Do you have some sample log events? I am concerned about not constraining the query by date, and separately unsure if activationid is indexed at splunk side (if it is indexed, date part of query may not matter, but we should verify this). 

If the splunk api returns different results for same query with different api users, that seems like a bug.

memory. This would reduce heap pressure for web actions and other

For kube the ansible changes obviously won't do anything.
What we would need to do is add pairs of stanza like the below to every pod specification in the Helm templates.

```
        volumeMounts:
        - mountPath: /etc/localtime
          name: localtime
          readOnly: true
```
```
      volumes:
      - name: localtime
        hostPath:
          path: /etc/localtime
```
I haven't tested this myself, but stackoverflow suggests it should work.
Would love to see this get pushed through.  There are some compensating changes we will need in kube-deploy; I will be happy to take care of them when it is time.

thing.

@mdeuser there's a problem with the dependencies in this playbook.

the routemgmt playbook runs last; when deploying this is ok since it will download `wsk` and install the package.

but if you teardown the system, this playbook cannot uninstall the package since the deployment is down at that point.

the playbook fails silently because a failed status code from `wsk` in the uninstall script is accepted; this leaves the package in the database.

should we pull this playbook out of openwhisk.yml - why isn't it part of the apigw playbook or just run explicitly?

you are correct.  the `clean` task depends on a live backend.  i like the idea of pulling it out of openwhisk.yml and explicitly calling it in the correct order.  i prefer to keep it out of the apigateway.yml playbook to keep these concerns separate.

OK let me try this:

```
openwhisk 
download cli
routemgmt
```

to teardown

```
routemgmt mode=clean # removes package
download cli mode=clean # removes cli
openwhisk mode=clean # teardown the system
```
@mdeuser there is a postdeploy playbook - it could also go in there; that playbook installs the various packages (aka catalog)... although that playbook doesn't clean itself :/
@mdeuser why not put it in the api gateway playbook? Logically it won't work without it.
@mdeuser can you take a look at this PR - I separated the routemgmt package installation as discussed on Slack.
